Course.title: Web Development
Course.code_template: Start with this empty project template to create your own web site.

Sample.title: Bootstrap Components
Sample.description: Explore a gallery of Bootstrap components.

Sample.title: Bootstrap Jumbotron
Sample.description: Explore how to build a web page around a jumbotron with a navbar and some basic grid columns.

Sample.title: Bootstrap Carousel
Sample.description: Explore how to build a web page with a carousel and a navbar.

Sample.title: Bootstrap Blog
Sample.description: Explore how to build a two-column blog page with custom navigation, header, and type.

Sample.title: Bootstrap Dashboard

Lesson.section: Start from here to learn web development! In these interactive lessons you will step-by-step learn to build websites with HTML, CSS and JavaScript.
Lesson.title: Hello World
Lesson.description: In this lesson you'll learn to build your first website.

Exercise.task: Press Run to view the website below.
Exercise.SourceCode:
Hello$code_hint$ World

This is my first website

Run.success: Great, you've just build your first website! You can see it below. Let's continue.

Exercise.task: Now modify the HTML code at the blue arrow in the web page below to show '_Hi World_'. Then run.

ExpectedCode.fail: Just change the text '_Hello World_' to '_Hi World_'.

Run.success: Awesome! You have changed the website to show '_Hi World_'.

Exercise.task: Congratulations, you've finished the first web development lesson! Now play with the code a bit on your own. Change the text which is shown and run it as often as you like. Then continue with the next lesson.

Lesson.title: Website Structure
Lesson.description: In this lesson you'll learn about the basic structure of a website using HTML, CSS and JavaScript.

Exercise.task: Press Run to view the website below.

Run.success: Great! Below you can see how a web browser displays the website. Let's see how it works.

Exercise.task: This is the main web page of this website. The HTML code in this file describes the visual elements of the web page. HTML is a markup language for describing web documents. Press on the blue arrow, then continue.
The HTML code uses a !_link_! tag to specify the CSS file !_styles.css_! for the visual styles of the page.
The HTML code uses a !_script_! tag to specify the JavaScript file !_scripts.js_! for the dynamic behavior of the page.
The CSS file !_styles.css_! defines the visual styles of the web page.
This !_font_size_! CSS style for example defines the font size in the body of the web page.
The JavaScript file !_scripts.js_! defines the dynamic behavior of the web page.
This JavaScript code for example makes the web page show the current date and time.

Run.success: As you see the web page displays the current date and time. Let's modify it a bit.

Exercise.task: Modify the HTML code at the blue arrow to show '_Current Time_'. Then run.

ExpectedCode.fail: Just change the text '_My Website_' to '_Current Time_'.

Exercise.task: Change the !_font_size_! to !_2em_!. Then run.

ExpectedCode.fail: Just change the line to !_font-size: 2em_!.

Run.success: Good job! You have customized the web page. Use the blue button below to open the web page in a real browser as well.

Exercise.task: Congratulations, you've learned about the basic structure of a website in this lesson! Now play with the code a bit on your own. Change the text which is shown and run it as often as you like. Then continue with the next lesson.

Lesson.section: Use HTML to code web pages
Lesson.title: Tags
Lesson.description: In this lesson you'll get to know HTML, the markup language for describing web pages.

Exercise.task: Press Run to view the website below. The website is described as HTML code, which a web browser can display as a document.
Exercise.SourceCode:
$code_hint$ $code_hint_2$

My first Heading

$code_hint_3$

This is a paragraph

$code_hint_4$ $code_hint_5$ $code_hint_1$

Run.success: Great! Below you can see how a web browser displays the HTML code as a web page. Let's continue.

Exercise.task: The blue arrow points to a HTML tag, which is a keyword surrounded by angle brackets. Press on the blue arrow, then continue.

HTML tags normally come in pairs like. The first tag in a pair is the opening tag, the second tag is the closing tag and is written with a slash. The whole text including both tags is called an element.
The text between the opening and closing !_body_! tags describes the visible page content. Each HTML tag describes different document content.
The text between the !_h1_! tags describes a heading.
The text between the !_p_! tags describes a paragraph.

Run.success: As you see our web page has one header and one paragraph. Let's add more content next.

Exercise.task: Add a second paragraph with the the text '_This is another paragraph_'.

ExpectedCode.fail:
Just add the code !_

This is another paragraph

_!.

Run.success: Good job!

Exercise.task: Congratulations, you've learned HTML basics in this lesson! Now play with the code a bit on your own. Change the text which is shown and run it as often as you like. Then continue with the next lesson.

Lesson.title: Images
Lesson.description: In this lesson you'll learn to include images in your web pages.

Exercise.task: Press Run to view the website below. It contains an image.

Run.success: Great! Let's learn how images work in HTML.

Exercise.task: The !_img_! tag is used to include an image.
The !_src_! attribute defines the image. Here the file !_img/android.jpg_! of this website project is used.
Add a second image with the file !_img/html.jpg_!.

ExpectedCode.fail: Add the code !__!.

Exercise.task: Congratulations, you've learned to include images in this lesson! Now play with the code a bit on your own. Change the text which is shown and run it as often as you like. Then continue with the next lesson.

Lesson.title: Links
Lesson.description: In this lesson you'll learn to include hyperlinks in your web pages.

Exercise.task: Press Run to view the website below. It contains a hyperlink that you can click on to open another web page.

Run.success: Great! Click on the '_Google_' link in this web page. Let's learn how links work in HTML.

Exercise.task: A hyperlink is defined with the !_a_! tag in HTML.
The !_href_! attribute of the !_a_! tag specifies the destination web page of the link. Here it is '_http://www.google.com_'.
The text between the opening and closing !_a_! tags is shown in the web page.
Add a second link to '_http://www.android.com_' with the the text '_Android_'.

ExpectedCode.fail: Add the link with the !_a_! tag !__!.
Add the text '_Android_' between the opening and closing !_a_! tags.

Run.success: Awesome! Test your newly added hyperlink.

Exercise.task: To use an image as a link add an image with the file !_img/android.jpg_! inside the !_a_! tags.

ExpectedCode.fail: Add the code !__! at the blue arrow.

Run.success: Great! Click on the image to follow the link.

Exercise.task: Congratulations, you've learned about links in this lesson! Now play with the code a bit on your own. Change the text which is shown and run it as often as you like. Then continue with the next lesson.

Lesson.title: Lists
Lesson.description: In this lesson you'll learn to include bullet lists in your web pages.

Exercise.task: Press Run to view the website below. It contains a list.

Run.success: Great! There's only on list item in this bullet list yet. Let's add some more.

Exercise.task: The !_ul_! tag is used to define a list in HTML.
Each list item is defined with an !_li_! tag.
Add a second list item with the text '_Android_'.

ExpectedCode.fail:

Exercise.task: Congratulations, you've learned about lists in this lesson! Now play with the code a bit on your own. Change the text which is shown and run it as often as you like. Then continue with the next lesson.

Lesson.section: Use CSS to define the visual appearance of your web pages
Lesson.title: CSS How To
Lesson.description: In this lesson you'll learn how to include CSS in your web page to define its visual styles.

Exercise.task: Press Run to view the website below.

Run.success: As you see this web page has a red heading. Let's see how this works.

Exercise.task: The !_h1_! tag has an inline !_style_! attribute which sets CSS styles.
Now change the CSS !_color_! style to !_Blue_!.

ExpectedCode.fail: Just change !_Red_! to !_Blue_!.

Run.success: Awesome! Now the heading is blue.

Exercise.task: Instead of a !_style_! attribute we use a !_style_! tag now, which can define styles for several tags of the web page.
Exercise.SourceCode:
h1$code_hint_1$ { color: Blue$code_hint_2$; } $code_hint_3$

My Website

A paragraph.

Exercise.task: Our internal style sheet defines a rule set for !_h1_! tags.
The rule set sets the CSS !_color_! style to !_Blue_!.

Run.success: Our heading is still blue.

Exercise.task: Now add a second rule set for !_p_! tags which sets the CSS !_color_! style to !_Green_!.

ExpectedCode.fail: Just add the CSS code !_p { color: Green; }_!.

Run.success: Good job! The paragraph text is green now.

Exercise.task: Instead of defining a !_style_! tag directly inside the HTML page, we now use a !_link_! tag to link to the external CSS file !_styles.css_! for the styles.
The CSS file !_styles.css_! contains the CSS rule sets for !_h1_! and !_p_!.

Run.success: The styles from the linked CSS files are still applied when the web page is displayed.

Exercise.task: Congratulations, you've learned how to include CSS in this lesson! Now play with the code a bit on your own. Change the text which is shown and run it as often as you like. Then continue with the next lesson.

Lesson.title: Class Selectors
Lesson.description: In this lesson you'll learn to use CSS class selectors to style HTML elements.

Exercise.task: Press Run to view the website below.
Exercise.SourceCode:
My Website

A paragraph.

Another paragraph.

Run.success: The web page has two paragraphs. Let's style them.

Exercise.task: In the CSS file we define a rule set for !_p_! tags which sets the !_color_! style to !_Blue_!.

Run.success: Both paragraphs are now blue. Let's learn to define a different color for each paragraph next.

Exercise.task: Instead of using a tag selector we now define a class selector !_blue-text_!. A class selector starts with a dot.
Exercise.SourceCode:
My Website

A paragraph.

Another paragraph.

Exercise.task: We set the class !_blue-text_! using a !_class_! attribute for the first !_p_! tag.

Run.success: Now only the first paragraph is blue because the CSS rule set only applies for HTML elements with the class !_blue-text_!. Let's make the second paragraph green.

Exercise.task: Add a CSS rule set for the class !_green-text_! which sets the !_color_! style to !_Green_!.

ExpectedCode.fail: Just add the CSS code !_.green-text { color: Green; }_!.

Exercise.task: Set the class !_green-text_! for the second paragraph.

ExpectedCode.fail: Add attribute !_class="green-text"_! at the blue arrow.

Run.success: Awesome! You have styled the second paragraph.

Exercise.task: Congratulations, you've learned to use CSS class selectors in this lesson! Now play with the code a bit on your own. Change the text which is shown and run it as often as you like. Then continue with the next lesson.

Lesson.section: Use JavaScript and DOM maninpulation to code the dynamic behavior of your web pages
Lesson.title: JavaScript How To
Lesson.description: In this lesson you'll learn how to include JavaScript in your web page to code its dynamic behavior.

Exercise.task: Press Run to view the website below.

Run.success: The web page opens an alert dialog with a message. Let's learn how to do this.

Exercise.task: The HTML code contains a !_script_! tag which defines JavaScript code that is executed when the web page is loaded.
The code calls the built-in JavaScript function !_alert_! which opens the dialog.
Change the message of the dialog to something else.

Run.success: Good job!

Exercise.task: We now use a !_src_! atribute in the !_script_! tag to include the external JavaScript file !_scripts.js_! instead of including the JavaScript code directly in HTML.
The JavaScript file !_scripts.js_! contains the !_alert_! function call.

Run.success: As you see the external JavaScript code is still executed when the page is displayed.

Exercise.task: Congratulations, you've learned how to include JavaScript in your web page in this lesson! Now play with the code a bit on your own. Change the text which is shown and run it as often as you like. Then continue with the next lesson.

Lesson.title: Events
Lesson.description: In this lesson you'll learn to react to user events in your web page.

Exercise.task: Press Run to view the website below.

Run.success: The web page contains an image. Let's implement an action when it is clicked.

Exercise.task: Add an attribute !_onclick="alert('Android')"_! to the !_img_! tag. The !_onclick_! attribute defines JavaScript that is executed when the element is clicked.

ExpectedCode.fail: Add the code !_onclick="alert('Android')"_! at the blue arrow.

Run.success: Good job! Now tap on the image.

Exercise.task: Change the !_alert('Android')_! call to !_showDialog()_! to call your own JavaScript function.

ExpectedCode.fail: Add the code !_onclick="showDialog()"_! at the blue arrow.

Exercise.task: We use a !_script_! tag to include JavaScript code from the !_scripts.js_! file.
In the !_scripts.js_! file add the JavaScript fucntion !_showDialog_!.

ExpectedCode.fail: Add the code !_function showDialog() {}_! at the blue arrow.

Exercise.task: Add a method call !_alert("Android")_! inside the !_showDialog_! function.

ExpectedCode.fail: Add the code !_alert("Android")_! at the blue arrow.

Run.success: Great! If you tap on the image now the !_showDialog_! function is called and shows the dialog.

Exercise.task: Congratulations, you've learned to react to events with JavaScript in this lesson! Now play with the code a bit on your own. Change the text which is shown and run it as often as you like. Then continue with the next lesson.

Lesson.title: DOM
Lesson.description: In this lesson you'll learn to access HTML elements from JavaScript.

Exercise.task: Press Run to view the website below.

Run.success: Let's make the web page show the current time from JavaScript.

Exercise.task: The !_p_! element has an !_id_! attribute !_time_!. The id makes it easy to access and manipulate the element from JavaScript code later.
The HTML code uses a !_script_! tag to include the JavaScript file !_scripts.js_!.
Add the JavaScript code !_var timeElement = document.getElementById("time");_! to access the HTML element in the document object model (DOM).

ExpectedCode.fail: Add the code !_var timeElement = document.getElementById("time");_! at the blue arrow.

Exercise.task: Now use the code !_timeElement.innerHTML = new Date();_! to actually change the HTML element to show the current date and time.

ExpectedCode.fail: Add the code !_timeElement.innerHTML = new Date();_! at the blue arrow.

Run.success: Awesome! The JavaScript code changes the paragraph to show the current date and time now.

Exercise.task: Congratulations, you've learned to access HTML elements from the JavaScript DOM in this lesson! Now play with the code a bit on your own. Change the text which is shown and run it as often as you like. Then continue with the next lesson.

Lesson.title: Interaction
Lesson.description: In this lesson you'll learn to use events and DOM manipulation to react to user interaction.

Exercise.task: Press Run to view the website below.

Run.success: Let's change the image when the user clicks on it.

Exercise.task: Set the !_id_! of the !_img_! element to !_myImage_!.

ExpectedCode.fail: Add attribute !_id="myImage"_! at the blue arrow.

Exercise.task: Add an !_onclick_! event handler which calls the function !_toggleImage()_!.

ExpectedCode.fail: Add attribute !_onclick="toggleImage()"_! at the blue arrow.

Exercise.task: The HTML code uses a !_script_! tag to include the JavaScript file !_scripts.js_!.
We have already added the event handler function !_toggleImage_!.
Now add the code !_var image = document.getElementById("myImage");_! to access the HTML image element.

ExpectedCode.fail: Add the code !_var image = document.getElementById("myImage");_! at the blue arrow.

Exercise.task: We have added an if statetment which toggles the !_src_! attribute of the HTML image element.

Run.success: Awesome! Now click on the image and see what happens.

Exercise.task: Congratulations, you've learned to implement user interaction inside the web page in this lesson! Now play with the code a bit on your own. Change the text which is shown and run it as often as you like. Then continue with the next lesson.
